title: Examination and Analysis Techniques
publication_title: Ivan Albright Paintings at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">Sinar rePro camera with 86H back (B+W Infrared 093 filter, PECA 918 UV/IR interference cut filter).

Westinghouse X-ray unit, scanned on Epson Expressions 10000XL flatbed scanner.

Sinar rePro with 86H back with internal IR filter removed, external Heliopan Infrared RG 830 (87c) filter (1.0–1.1 µm); Goodrich/Sensors Unlimited SU640SDV-1.7RT (0.9–1.7 µm) with H filter (1.1–1.4 µm) and J filter (1.5–1.7 µm).

Sample and cross-sectional analysis were performed using a Zeiss Axioplan2 research microscope equipped with reflected light/UV fluorescence and a Zeiss AxioCam MRc5 digital camera. Types of illumination used: darkfield, differential interference contrast (DIC), and UV. In situ photomicrographs were taken with Wild Heerbrugg M7A StereoZoom microscope fitted with Olympus DP71 microscope digital camera.

Several spots on the paintings were analyzed in situ with a Bruker TRACeR III-V with rhodium tube.

Samples were mounted on a Specac diamond compression cell for analysis by FTIR. Data were collected in transmission mode between 4000 and 400 cm<sup>-1</sup> at 4 cm<sup>-1</sup> resolution and 128 scans per spectrum using a Bruker Hyperion microscope with MCT D315 detector, interfaced to a Tensor 27 spectrometer bench.

For in-situ analysis, a Bruker Alpha small footprint portable FTIR spectrometer was used in noncontact, reflection mode.

Cross sections were analyzed after carbon coating with Hitachi S-3400N-II VP-SEM with an Oxford EDS and a Hitachi solid-state BSE detector.

Thread count and weave information were determined by Thread Count Automation Project software.

Overlay images registered using a novel image-based algorithm developed by Damon M. Conover (GW), Dr. John K. Delaney (GW, NGA), and Murray H. Loew (GW) of the George Washington University’s School of Engineering and Applied Science, and the National Gallery of Art, Washington, DC.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">See Don H. Johnson, C. Richard Johnson, Jr., Andrew G. Klein, William A. Sethares, H. Lee, and Ella Hendriks, “A Thread Counting Algorithm for Art Forensics,” 2009 IEEE Thirteenth Digital Signal Processing and Fifth IEEE Signal Processing Education Workshop (IEEE, 2009), pp. 679–84; doi:10.1109/DSP.2009.4786009.

See Damon M. Conover, John K. Delaney, Paola Ricciardi, and Murray H. Loew, “Towards Automatic Registration of Technical Images of Works of Art,” in Computer Vision and Image Analysis of Art II, ed. David G. Stork, James Coddington, and Anna Bentkowska-Kafel, Proc. SPIE 7869 (SPIE/IS&T, 2011); doi:10.1117/12.872634.

</section>
